awd_titl_txt: Role of the FEI/ACC pathway in regulating cell wall synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant cells are surrounded by a semi-rigid wall that is made primarily of chains of sugars. This plant cell wall provides structural support, defines the size and shape of cells, and provides a barrier to infection by pathogens. Plant cell walls are diverse and highly dynamic structures that respond to developmental and environmental cues. The main load-bearing component of plant cell walls is cellulose, which is made at the surface of cells by a large enzyme complex called cellulose synthase. In this project, it will be characterized how plants regulate how much cellulose they make. Prior work uncovered a pathway that controls this process by modulating the movement of the cellulose synthase complex to the cell surface. How this pathway works and how it interacts with the other elements in the cell to control cellulose synthase will be explored. Further, a novel signaling molecule, 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC), a precursor to ethylene, was found to act in this pathway. How ACC is perceived by cells and how it acts to modulate cellulose synthase function will be determined. The results from this work will provide insight into how plants regulate cell wall biosynthesis, which is crucial to understanding the development of plant form and other processes and is important for the burgeoning biofuels industry. This project will interact with programs designed to increase the representation of minorities in the sciences and several outreach programs that aim to increase the public understanding of plant science.

A signaling pathway regulating cell wall synthesis has been defined that includes the FEI receptor-like kinases, SHOU4 (a novel transmembrane protein), and ACC acting as a signal independent of its conversion to ethylene. Prior results suggest that this pathway regulates CESA (cellulose synthase) function by modulating CESA trafficking to the plasma membrane. A diverse set of complementary experiments are proposed to further elucidate how this pathway regulates CESA function. A primary hypothesis that will be tested is that SHOU4 acts as a counter of CESA levels at the PM, with the complex generating a signal to negatively regulate CESA exocytosis to maintain optimal levels of cellulose biosynthesis. One key aspect of this model is the direct interaction of SHOU4 and CESA. This interaction will be further characterized, including elucidating the role of phosphorylation, potentially by the FEI kinases. Outputs of this complex will be identified by screening for proteins that interact with SHOU4. A second hypothesis that will be tested is that ACC negatively regulates CESA function. A genetic screen was used to identify elements involved in ACC perception. These mutant lines will be further characterized and the genes corresponding to these mutations will be cloned and characterized. These studies will increase the understanding of how cell wall biosynthesis is regulated, a process that is central to many aspects of plant growth and development and which is important for the burgeoning biofuels industry. Further, these studies will begin to define the mechanisms underlying ACC function in plants.

This award was co-funded by the Physiological Mechanisms and Biomechanics Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plant cells are surrounded by a semi-rigid wall that is made primarily of chains of sugars. This plant cell wall provides structural support, defines the size and shape of cells, and provides a barrier to infection by pathogens and is an important source of fuel, building material, and fiber for humans. Plant cell walls are diverse and highly dynamic structures that respond to developmental and environmental cues. In the research supported by this award, we studied pathways regulating the biosynthesis of the cell wall. A key regulator examined was a protein called SHOU4, which controls the delivery of CesA complexes, to the cell surface. These CesA complexes synthesize cellulose, the primary load-bearing element of the cell wall and the most abundant polymer on earth. We found that a number of other signaling pathways act through SHOU4 to modulate wall biosynthesis, including the phytohormone brassinosteroid and a key regulatory protein kinase called FERONIA, both of which modulate SHOU4 function through phosphorylation.  Additionally, we identified and characterized a number of proteins that interact with SHOU4 that we found also play a role in controlling cell wall function. Our results suggest that SHOU4 acts a key integrator of multiple inputs to regulate cell wall synthesis by modulating the localization CesA complexes and hence the level of cellulose biosynthesis.

We also explored the role of a molecule called 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate, or ACC, in regulating wall function. ACC is well known as a precursor of ethylene, a phytohormone involved in many plant processes. However, in addition to this role, we showed that ACC itself acts to modulate cell wall function independent of ethylene. We demonstrated that this action of ACC happens fairly slowly, taking at least 36 hours to inhibit root growth. Consistent with this, analysis of gene expression demonstrated that at relatively short treatment times (≤ 2 hours), ACC has no effect on gene expression, but in response to prolonged treatment times, the expression of many genes is altered, including many that are linked to cell wall function. This work suggest that ACC does not act in the roots via a simple, canonical receptor-signal transduction paradigm, but rather likely alters the level of some factor (or some aspect of cell wall function) slowly over time that then affects root growth when a critical concentration is reached.

In a distinct vein of work, we explored the role of autophagy in the response to another phytohormone, cytokinin, in Arabidopsis. Autophagy is a major catabolic pathway that maintains cellular homeostasis in response to intrinsic developmental changes and environmental cues by targeting proteins for degradation and recycling. Our work provides a mechanistic link between cytokinin and autophagy, demonstrating that autophagy can fine-tune cytokinin perception by modulating the level of the type-A ARRs, which are negatively regulators of the cellular response to cytokinin. Further, our work sheds light on the mechanism of selective autophagy and on how a particular cargo is targeted for autophagic degradation.

This grant supported the training of numerous undergraduate, Ph.D. students, and postdoctoral fellows, included many from underrepresented groups. Further, this grant help support several projects aimed at communicating science to the general public. This included the design and presentation of a program at the UNC Science Expo focused on rice. We also gave several presentation at a program called “Science in the Stacks” at UNC, with presentations geared toward K-12 students, as well as presentation at “Science in the News” focused on current science topics.
